# Leo

| 2024-04-16 | Review of SCZD vs NTC DE models | I explained why `age > 17` is a must for SCZD vs NTC DGE analyses: we have no SCZD cases with `age <= 17`, so if you don't filter the NTC donors with `age <=17`, you end up basically comparing older (SCZD) vs younger (NTC) donors, which is not what you want to do. We also talked about how in BSP2 there are some HPC (HIPPO) samples from 2 RiboZero protocols (Gold and HMR), how the Gold HPC samples cluster with the DLPFC ones on PC1 vs PC2, and thus why we ended up dropping the 43 Gold HPC samples in previous work (see https://github.com/LieberInstitute/qsva_brain/blob/cba8fa5e886be9242dcbaae7854d1eed0f69cef5/brainseq_phase2_qsv/make_qSVs.R#L62-L69). This information is reflected by `analysis_sczd_casecontrol_hippo` at https://s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/libd-brainseq2/methprop_pd.Rdata listed at https://eqtl.brainseq.org/phase2/. Finally, I emphasized that self-reported `race` is not a trustworthy variable and we instead rely on `snpPC`s. |
| 2024-04-15 | Options for creating links to use in manuscripts | I explained why using something like https://research.libd.org/spatialDLPFC/#interactive-websites or https://research.libd.org/globus/ give us control over links that we might need to update later on, instead of including other less stable links on manuscripts (domains we don't control, tools that might change their URL syntax, etc). I provided links to how to make each option such as https://github.com/LieberInstitute/spatialDLPFC/blob/main/code/update_website.R and https://github.com/LieberInstitute/globus/blob/98dc479ad2cde0a047cf7a46769a85c32969b7b1/index.Rmd#L8-L37. |

| 2024-04-03 | Avoid using jsonlite when editing spaceranger json files | We found out that `spaceranger count` did not like the JSON files we created with `jsonlite::write_json()` so instead, we edited them manually using `gsub()` and `read/writeLines()` as documented [here](https://github.com/LieberInstitute/LFF_spatial_ERC/commit/bbf810ad39012ba6ee4e0403063bf83bf844d007). Note that we had to manuallly revert the JSON files to their original state as documented [here](https://github.com/LieberInstitute/LFF_spatial_ERC/commit/79ed5479d502cd41d51f3aa8ee1467bd8100a08a). |
| 2024-04-02 | Write a script to manually edit spaceranger json files | We wrote a script to manually update the json files and add the Visium Slide ID as well as the capture area. This will enable us to not have to use `--unknown-slide=visium-1` https://github.com/LieberInstitute/LFF_spatial_ERC/blob/6e85c05ce9f531c555569e616f8d5c351b427b4f/code/01_spaceranger/spaceranger_SLURM.sh#L63 that 10x Genomics support had recommended using. Doing so led to an error at https://github.com/LieberInstitute/LFF_spatial_ERC/blob/b5b92a8bb9744ee424ec4a0642ae692423a91d56/code/01_spaceranger/logs/spaceranger_17.txt#L22 which stated that `--slide` cannot be used as the same time as `--unknown-slide`. This is a workaround that was previously manually implemented at https://github.com/LieberInstitute/Habenula_Visium. Since we have lots of samples, we wrote a script to avoid introducing copy-paste errors. |
| 2024-04-01 | Debugging spaceranger count | The issue on this [script](https://github.com/LieberInstitute/LFF_spatial_ERC/blob/e913ff28fffbb17335d3844d312ec6486a7b182f/code/01_spaceranger/spaceranger_SLURM.sh#L55) and related ones is that there is a missing `\ ` (note the space) before the `#` comment symbol. Thus the chained command is breaking into two, and the second half is not being recognized as options to the first half. |
| 2024-03-29 | Understanding a spaceranger error | We worked on the following error message from `spaceranger count`: _ERROR: We detected a mixture of different R1 lengths ([26-28]), which breaks assumptions in how UMIs are tabulated and corrected. To process these data, you will need to truncate to the shortest observed R1 length by providing 26 to the --r1-length argument if are running count/vdj, or via the r1-length parameter in each of the following tables of your multi config CSV if you are running multi: [gene-expression]_. We inspected the soft links for the FASTQ files and used `zcat fastq.gz | head` to inspect the first few lines of FASTQ files. We confirmed that the `R1` FASTQs were indeed of varying lenghts and will attempt a new `spaceranger count` run using `--r1-length = 26` though it's likely that we'll next get an error with the `R2` FASTQ files as we observed that those files also have varying lengths. |
| 2024-03-25 | LIBD Data Portal for BSP1 and BSP2 DLPFC SCZD vs NTC data | I explained that BSP1 is polyA, aligned vs hg19, older annotation, aligned with TopHat2 (an older aligner). BSP2 is RiboZeroGold for DLPFC and RiboZeroHMR for HIPPO (with 43 RiboZeroGold samples that were dropped from the DE analysis), aligned vs hg38, against Gencode v25 (from July 2016), aligned with HISAT2. I also explained the naming structure of a Supplementary Table for BSP1's paper where `adj`, `qSVA`, and `PCA` are labels specifying whether it was a model `adj`usting for covariates, whether it adjusts for qSVs using `qSVA` (the better model to use), or adjusting for gene-level expression PCs (`PCA`). These names are related to the [`qSVA` 2017 paper](https://www.pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.1617384114) Figure 2. I also explained how in the BSP2 paper we did re-align the BSP1 data against hg38, though there is no Supplementary Table showing which of the 243 DLPFC DEGs replicated in BSP1 (though the data does exist since it was used to make Figure S28 and S29). We would need another DSgs or two to actually locate the data and construct an CSV file or table that others can use if they are interested in replication of BSP2 results using BSP1 and/or CommonMind Consortium (CMC) Phase 1 data (that was aligned vs hg19 with TopHat2). I also used [this slide](https://speakerdeck.com/lcolladotor/libd-ds-tldr?slide=56) to explain all the pieces that go into a DEG model and why the visualizations provided by the LIBD Data Portal (boxplots for SCZD vs NTC) are just a visual guide using normalized gene expression data and not the full answer (as the LIBD Data Portal doesn't use the full details we include in a DEG model). |
| 2024-03-22 | Polishing details on how to ask for help effectively | We disscussed specific details on how to ask for help. For example, it's ok to ask those around you in person but you should also ask on the `#libd_helpdesk` channel (and update the channel if someone else gave you an answer). That is, don't assume that only those around you (in person) know the answer. We went over details on how to preview GitHub messages (to verify that they are correctly formatted), why GitHub issues are useful to the authors, what information is needed for others to help you answer a question (R session info, `reprex::reprex()` output, link to code on a public GitHub repo; private is ok when asking internally for help). We also discussed the overall idea of why learning how to make an R package will be useful to then improve one's tooltik for debugging R packages made by others. |

| 2022-08-24 | How can I interpret the y-axis from `plotExplanatoryVariables()`? | Density is related to the probability density function, see [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_density_estimation for) more details. [This link](https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/4220/can-a-probability-distribution-value-exceeding-1-be-ok) is also useful for understanding the y-axis in more detail. Violin plots are just density plots rotated 90 degrees and mirrored. They are compared against boxplots frequently, which while easier to understand, are not good for non-unimodal data. See [this link](https://mode.com/blog/violin-plot-examples/#:~:text=What%20is%20a%20violin%20plot%3F,the%20density%20of%20each%20variable) for more. I like `plotExplanatoryVariables()` because it's fast to run and gives a general idea of things. See [Figure 1b](https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/vignettes/variancePartition/inst/doc/variancePartition.pdf) from `variancePartition` for a violin plot of similar data. `variancePartition` can handle mixed effects models (random effects) and in that scenario is more precise, but will also take longer to compute. |
| 2022-08-17 | DE analysis introduction | Check [EnchancedVolcano](https://bioconductor.org/packages/devel/bioc/vignettes/EnhancedVolcano/inst/doc/EnhancedVolcano.html) which shows a quick DE guide and finishes with some Volcano plots, which can be good enough for a grant application. If you want to use limma, you could follow [the SPEAQeasy example](http://research.libd.org/SPEAQeasy-example/de_analysis_speaqeasy.html#16_Modeling) or [our DE bootcamp](http://research.libd.org/SPEAQeasy-example/bootcamp_intro#5_Day_3) a bit. Or dive deeper into [limma's documentation](http://bioconductor.org/packages/release/workflows/vignettes/RNAseq123/inst/doc/limmaWorkflow.html). |

Next, you might want to check the bsseq documentation https://bioconductor.org/packages/bsseq/ if you are interested in finding differentially methylated regions (DMRs) and in any case, because BiocMAP provides that type of R object as noted at http://research.libd.org/BiocMAP/outputs.html. https://jhubiostatistics.shinyapps.io/wgbsExprs/ and the companion paper is the last WGBS data analysis project I did myself with code at https://github.com/LieberInstitute/brain-epigenomics. Kira Perzel-Mandell, who worked with Shizhong, wrote https://github.com/LieberInstitute/wgbs_meqtl_analysis (link to paper there) and did other projects. If you are plotting methylation levels at some locations, then that's very direct. If you are trying to find DMRs, it can take a bit of time to get used to the large objects and the related complications (once you filter the data, it'll be more manageable). If you go into CpH instead of CpG, then memory constraints become harder to deal with. |

| 2021-03-24 | Explain the feasibility of an on-demand end user interface for DEG and eQTLs | To identify DEGs or eQTLs, the user has to choose what covariates to adjust for. Some studies might require more complicated models than others, as they might be from more than one brain region or present some batch effect. In addition, in newer projects we are considering adjusting for cell type fractions derived from deconvolution. Even if all the covariates were fixed across datasets, in DEGs we have typically adjusted for qSVs which are computed in a dataset-dependent fashion and in essence are PCs derived from degradation-associated genomic regions. Similarly, for eQTLs we adjust for expression PCs. In both we adjust for ancestry PCs. Computing PCs is input-dependent: you won't get the same values or PCs if you change which samples you are using. So, computing DEGs and eQTLs is not as simple as say a map-reduce problem where you compute the same thing for every input sample, then aggregate the per-sample results. We have steps that depend on the whole sample set. Then there's also steps for filtering expression features based on some minimum expression cutoffs. Plus, differences between say polyA and RiboZero data, which don't make sense to process together. For these reasons, I don't think that an on-demand computation pipeline is feasible based on a user selecting a set of input samples. Constructing RNA-seq objects (RangedSummarizedExperiment objects) as well as DNA genotyping VCF files based on a set of input samples is feasible and that's what others are building. After that, I think that it's best to adapt code we have (or even use newer tools) after carefully exploring the data. |
